p: The US has a wide range of research fields for infectious disease preparedness ranging from basic research (i.e., the identification and mechanism of the viral pathogen) (62.0%) to animal–environmental ecology and the epidemiologic investigation and quarantine of infectious diseases (23.8%) and has invested from a mid- to long-term perspective (see Figure 3). Although the funding scale for coronavirus-related R&D areas in the EU and Japan is smaller than that of the United States, the directions for the R&D areas are considerably analogous to those in the US. These trends in coronavirus-related R&D funding show that the directions for the R&D investment are in accordance with the “One Health” concept of the WHO, which is a global strategy for all aspects of healthcare for the environment–animal–human paradigm [ 33].
